commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Didn't get broken  (4)(5)
2. Takes in the trash?  (7)(6)
3. In need of an evening out?  (7)
4. They go from season to season  (5)(4)
5. Clown around with food?  (8)


HELD SERVE
DELETED SCENES
CREASED
STORY ARCS
MCDONALD

Congrats Brian on your debut and I look forward to your next one!
I think this was a cute theme and nicely executed for the most part. I definitely wasn‚Äôt a big fan of HIGH FIVE to be honest, because the HI is so close to the word HIGH, and not so much because it was split but jn the wrong order. (I get that if FIVE was at the bottom you have to finds a word for G‚ÄîV, but even second to the last row? Or don‚Äôt use it and find something else?) But that‚Äôs a minor annoyance in an otherwise nice Monday debut so kudos!
Isn't the id's counterpart the superego, with the ego serving as mediator? It's been a while since I've touched up on Freud, so to speak.
Two ops?  I guess ok since they are short for different things: operations and opportunity.
Toughie of a Monday! But great!

Not a fan of both the mini and regular crossword on the same day having the same clue with same answer.

Walgreens competitor... CVS

Congratulations on your debut, Brian.

You definitely had me going more than a typical Monday.  Several times I feel for the bait.  For example, THINKINGhAt rather than THINKINGCAP, made me wonder what kind of instrument a hELLO was.

Likewise, I had AVEnA for 69A (I know absolutely nothing about skin products) which made me wonder why a Bro was a DUnE.

And just to make sure I had all the answers wrong initially, I confidently but in CHICKENfiNgERS.

You managed to hit all my incorrect instincts!

Good thing I don't solve on stone tablets.

It's looking very much like IGOTTAJET is going to cost me a month of gold this month.

Oh, well.  I probably cheated and forgot about it.

The theme was MEH but this was a fair difficulty level .. not too easy not too hard. I almost got stuck at the NOVAC / JACKSON cross but eventually just took a guess at the football coach's name and it planned out. 
Only other hard one was ATTA which wouldn't have been possible for me without the NAME cross .. what is a "proper name" anyway?

As others have said, tough Monday. 4-down not being KITCH threw me off the NW though I now realized I didn't even spell it right. Maybe it's just me but MPAA was also tricky, turning that and POI into a bit of a natick.

Congratulations on your debut, Brian. This was AOK in my book. Perfect Monday level of difficulty with a theme easy enough to discern. I did have my HIGH and FIVE reversed as I assumed (which one should never do) that HIGH would be on top. Silly me üòÜ I completely forgot that PHIL JACKSON took over coaching the Lakers after Pat Riley ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è That was a complete d‚Äôoh moment for this LA native. I only remembered him as the Bulls coach. Anyway,  once I put my THINKING CAP on, the clouds disappeared and everything was clear. Do people still send GREETING CARDS anymore? I think Hallmark was smart to branch out into the lucrative movie industry or they would probably be out of business by this point. Who knows ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Happy Monday Crosslandia!

Am still on Mon. & Tues., though Mon. offers me the most success. So, just got on a little while ago, and am already finding that I can't answer most of the clues. What's going on?  I would conjecture that this isn't a Mon. puzzle at all. Would like to politely ask, why, then, do you have to put a puzzle of this level of difficulty on Mon.? I don't think that's very fair & a poor start to a new week. Maybe you should rethink the order that you post the puzzles. This new puzzle-maker would probably have a better reception later in the week. [[Even Tues-Wed].
Several really delightful clues in this one!

Fun puzzle, congratulations on the debut, Brian, and looking forward to seconds!

Slightly under average time for a Monday for me so I think I was near Brian's wavelength, based on some of the other feedback in the comments. After last week's doozies, I felt I was due!

It seems odd to have HI in 23-across that‚Äôs not part of the theme, doesn‚Äôt it?

Found this on the tougher side for a Monday, but figured out the theme from 56-across, which helped!
Fun one, but a bit tough for a Monday. Almost doubled my normal Monday time
HI FIVE to the constructor. It's been said that puns are the highest intelligent form of humor. I hope so, because I just love them. I enjoyed today's puzzle. HI HI HI!!!
Congrats on the debut puzzle! Fun theme, well done!
A Worthy Monday!

I enjoyed this puzzle a lot‚Ä¶ somehow hit a positive spot.

The grid layout looks like a face card to me.
i have absolutely no idea about what the circled letters have to do with greeting cards

The theme... Just, no. Was it supposed to be funny? Was the revealer so awesome as to justify the inane concept of greeting playing cards, of all things? I shudder to think what the unaccepted submissions of this constructor must have been like.

The trivia-heavy fill annoyed me, especially in the NW corner. FDIC... Really? Some letter salad on a Monday? Barry Ancona will tell me I should have relied on crosses, but those were not Andrzej-friendly, either. All I know about bowling is that it exists, I've never heard of an EYE KIT, and don't get me started on beverage brands... I'm not familiar with most Polish ones, even.

Elsewhere I was confused by the clue for GANG, but the column explained it to me.

The solve took me as long as a Wednesday usually does, and I enjoyed nothing about it. I was way past a MEH reaction.

The possiblity to WAIVE rights is very limited in most European countries, including Poland. Basic rights, workers' rights, consumer rights - none of those may ever be waived under Polish law. I was surprised and actually kinda freaked out by some of the disclaimers and waivers I encountered on our American vacations in 2011 and 2013.

Congratulations on your NYT puzzle debut, Mr. Keller! Nicely done!

The revealer was a bit more of a groaner than I like, but the clueing was overall pretty fun.

Thanks! I hope we'll see you back here soon!
Thought this was tougher than a typical Monday, but maybe my THINKINGCAP was too tight

Nice puzzle, 8D worthy of any day of the week and no thank you to Deb for planting the thought of a streaks of NYT editors. üòÄ 

Re solving times: Unless you‚Äôve been playing the crossword for absolutely ever your average is significantly higher than the mode (the most probable) of the distribution of your solving times. Unless the puzzle stumps you you should be doing better than average.
I'm giving this debut puzzle a high five, and many kudos to you for your persistence, Brian! Keep on puzzling and crafting!

Ive been thinking that Mondays have been getting more difficult for quite a while and said so in my comments.  Today‚Äôs puzzle definitely was continuing that pattern in my opinion.  Doesn‚Äôt mean I didn‚Äôt enjoy it though.
Having IGOR on top of CELLO today made my eyes widen, as my flatmate - a cellist - is currently practising for a performance of The Firebird. Bizarre and synchronous!

I've been doing Monday jigsaws without any help recently, but this was quite obscure for me, and not so enjoyable. I know 'obscure' is completely subjective, but a business owners magazine? HIC?

People actually say, "Feel me?" and "Ya dig?" I expect they must do. MERCH. SWAG. Today I feel I'm the wrong generation!

I've learnt about GPAS and PSATS and A LA mode so at least I got them. 

small sigh
Cute little groaner of a theme with more going on than the typical Monday.
Keep those submissions coming!
Fine Monday.  I couldn't find a blog post for the Sunday puzzle. Am I alone in that??

Wonderfully sweet theme ‚Äì I thought of a very young kid looking at cards and saying hello to them.  

I also thought of a card player looking at the hand they're holding, seeing desired cards, and, happily surprised, inwardly saying hi to them one by one. 

So, I was totally charmed.  Quirky and lovely theme, and, given that this is a debut NYT puzzle, I‚Äôm excited to see more from the mind that came up with it!

Myself, a palindrome fan, I didn‚Äôt actually say hi to the four in the grid ‚Äì two 3s, a four, and a five (ONO, ALA, ATTA, REFER) ‚Äì but it was the same hello feeling, increasingly happily surprised as each new one turned up.

Brian, I admire your persistence at continuing to submit puzzles even after 13 NYT rejections (Hi, @Mike!), and am very happy to hear that there are more to come.  I loved this puzzle ‚Äì thank you!
HI, TEN? At least the other theme entries had a somewhat common usage. Or is it HIghTEN? A bit of a stretch. Good puzzle nevertheless.

Fun Monday puzzle. Fairly smooth solve; just a lot of working the crosses. And... must confess I wasn't catching on to the theme until I was done and went back and reviewed. No big deal - just made for a nice moment of pondering. 

Puzzle find today was... quite unusual. I'll put that in a reply. 

....

Loved the misdirection in the cluing!
I LOL at 40D!!
Only gripe is that Aveda is not a skin care brand, but a hair care brand. And on that note‚Ä¶ take it from a makeup-wearer, ‚Äúeye kit‚Äù is not a thing.

Word-nerd post alert ‚Äì re NECTAR.  

Looks like it should end with an AR-as-in-TAR sound, but actually ends with ER as in HER.   

I wondered if there were more examples, came up with a couple (MORTAR, SOLAR), went online and found a ton more ‚Äì ALTAR, TARTAR, SIMILAR, VULGAR, REGULAR, PECULIAR, CIRCULAR, POPULAR, PARTICULAR, FAMILIAR, SINGULAR, CELLULAR, ANGULAR, SECULAR, and LUNAR. 

But why, I wondered?  ChatGPT said that many of these words had the ‚Äúahr‚Äù sound in Latin, and English kept the spelling, even as the pronunciation shifted over the centuries.  Why did the pronunciation shift?  Because in English, unstressed syllables often get reduced to the schwa sound, and thus that ‚Äúahr‚Äù sound became ‚Äúer‚Äù.

You‚Äôre welcome.

Ew! One more puzzle find. Once again don't recall ever seeing another one like this. A Sunday from June 4, 2000 by Martin Schneider with the title: "Spell Checker." Some clue/answer examples: "Champion on the ice" ENAITCHELALLSTAR "Many a college teaching assistant" PEEAITCHDEESTUDENT "Cold war warriors" KAYGEEBEEAGENTS "Prominent media member" CEEENENREPORTER "Las Vegas landmark" EMGEEEMGRAND "Theater hit of 1878" AITCHEMESSPINAFORE And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/4/2000&g=23&d=A ....
Clever and fun debut.  Looking forward to #2, and more.

HI Brian! Thanks for a fun puzzle.

I like it when Mondays have a little something extra, in this case the circled letters and theme. It spices up what might otherwise be a routine easy solve.
Gotta love a puzzle constructor who credits his mom! This was a fun Monday puzzle. I had HIGH and FIVE in the reverse locations at first, but once I fixed that, the solving was a smooth as silk.

it happened again today.  A word that appeared as the answer in the mini-puzzle appeared in the main crossword (CVS).  I've noticed this happening before where the same word that aoppears in one puzzle appears in another--including Strands and Connections.  Is this intentional or just coincidence?  Thoughts?

Not much really spoke to me in today's puzzle except:
- 70A (HIGH),then zip on across to 72A (REFER). But he redeemed himself with 60D (REEF). The rest, as they say, is all in your head.
- And another one of my favorite Old English ‚Äúa‚Äù words‚Ä¶ AWASH.
- Oh, and YADIG? How I miss slappin, dappin and rappin with my black brothers in the 70s. ‚ÄúYa feel me‚Äù doesn't even compare, sorry.

Wonderful start to the week and congratulations to the constructor! Loved the word play within the crossword format. Whenever I solve a puzzle I feel like all those that taught me how are invisibly but palpably sitting in the room with me. This puzzle felt like one I would have solved with Aunt Ruth at the old line kitchen table in the pink kitchen. Thanks again!

I was a college student when streaking was, I hesitate to say, popular. I never really understood why. But I do recall having to make room for the latest streaker running through the student union, out where we were sitting with our legs dangling in the cement "bowl," so he could get through in a straight line. We didn't even pause our conversation, or look up to see who it was. I do recall it was never a woman, always a man, and nobody seemed to care much. And yet, here we are, 50+ years later, with the term still popping up in our puzzles.

I can't help wondering what my life would have been like if my mommy had dressed me in a thinking cap instead of a dunce cap.

I guess I could stop wearing it, but it goes with everything!

Now look, I‚Äôm post ‚Äòflu plus post heavy wedding weekend (those Scousers know how to party), so that‚Äôs my excuse for struggling with large sections of today‚Äôs grid. I was AWASH with blank spaces for an embarrassingly long time and couldn‚Äôt see the theme at all, despite the circles. 
I finished at a snails pace, read Wordplay and finally realised that I‚Äôd misplaced my THINKING CAP. I‚Äôm getting too old to party all night. Didn‚Äôt stop me trying though, as my sore feet/head/back can attest,
Good grid.
Shoulda been a Tuesday!

How in the world can ‚ÄúHi ten‚Äù Be parsed as a greeting?

The only thing I can think of is a double high-five‚Ä¶but I really hope someone will tell me that I‚Äôm missing a much better interpretation.

Otherwise, yeah it was a little tough for a Monday; but I actually liked that aspect just fine, as I would personally like to see a little more *variability* in the difficulty of early-week puzzles (just to spice things up).

Oh, what the heck - one more puzzle. A Sunday from July 1, 1984 by Robert H. Wolfe with the title: "Letter Carrier." Some theme clues and answers: "Was obsessed with a single idea" HADABINONESBONNET "A certain tax revolt" THEBOSTONTPARTY "Line in a patriotic song" FROMCTOSHININGC "Is watchful" KEEPSONESISPEELED "Astaire film: 1941" ULLNEVERGETRICH Here's that Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=7/1/1984&g=26&d=A ...

I have nothing to share about the Monday puzzle (although I thought it was a pretty good one).  I write to note the passing of constructor Mel Taub whose obituary appears in today‚Äôs NYT.  Mel provided me many hours of pleasure over the years and I am saddened to learn of his death.  The paper version of the NYT (for any fellow dinosaurs) has a sprightly PandA by Mel as a bonus to lessen the sting.
In my opinion, the crossword lurches way too far over the line to commercialization when its theme is based on the products of a particular named company.

Congrats on your debut Brian. Since much angst has been expressed thus far, I thought I‚Äôd add another data point in the ‚Äúthis was a normal Monday‚Äù column. 

My solve came in under 10 mins without any lookups, which is almost 5 minutes under my Monday average. For context, I‚Äôve been doing the puzzle for about six months now (the app says 298 puzzles, that must include the archive). 

Sure, I‚Äôm immersed in American pop culture, and I was a huge NBA fan in the Michael Jordan era; helpful. 

I‚Äôm sympathetic to the plight of folks without those frames of reference, but aren‚Äôt bits of trivia expected in clues? I often watch BBC quiz and/or comedy shows (such as Countdown) that are filled with British humor and trivia. Personally, I connect much better with the former, but don‚Äôt let my lack of knowledge of the latter ruin the fun. Maybe I‚Äôm just chill since it went my way today. I‚Äôve definitely come here with a proverbial pitchfork on other occasions üòÖ

I still really struggle at times, and I‚Äôm, admittedly, not a purist when it comes down to looking up an obscure trivia clue when I‚Äôm really stuck (usually Saturday). I lean into the ‚ÄúI‚Äôm learning something new‚Äù attitude with regard to those obscure (to me) clues. Historical actors, authors, poets, and musicians are a particularly weak area for me. 

Thanks to you all for the banter, it‚Äôs appreciated, usually silently. ‚ò∫Ô∏è

HIGH FIVE to the Polish people for pierogi. üáµüá±ü•ü
HIGH FIVE to the punsters everywhere. ü§ì

I found the Mini as hard for its size as the regular puzzle. I managed to fill it all in, but remain stumped by 20% of it, like why SWIPE for 3D and SIM for 7D. Would I have known, in pre-dementia days? Or are they too new?
I don‚Äôt think ‚Äúhi ten‚Äù is a thing.  A so-so puzzle overall but throwing in nonsense like this makes it sub par.
Congratulations on a fine debut, Brian, and thanks for sharing your inspiring submission perseverance. Your ability to stay the course offers us all hope on so many levels!
Congrats on the debut! I thought this was a perfectly breezy Monday with a fun, punny twist. I loved CAT TOY and STREAK. Looking forward to your second puzzle!
So, AVEDA must be a skin care product regularly used at Hogwarts, right?

I found it crunchy for a Monday but have no complaints. It meant I didn‚Äôt really get the reveal until the crossword was completed, and then I could enjoy it in all its punificent glory. 

Nice debut!

Congrats on your NYT crossword debut! 

Maybe I‚Äôm missing something but I don‚Äôt quite get the theme. If we‚Äôre saying ‚Äúhi‚Äù to playing cards, they need a suit. ‚ÄúFive‚Äù isn‚Äôt a playing card. Maybe adding a suit in italics to the clue might have helped. Or maybe that makes it too easy. 

And if they‚Äôre not playing cards I have no idea what those four words have in common.
Just finished Saturday.  What a workout! Great puzzle.
good stuff! i find mondays to be a nice treat after the weekend puzzles.

I cannot access ‚ÄúTrading Punches‚Äù no matter how many times I try. The puzzle I get, marked 9/28/25, is ‚ÄúCentral Perk.‚Äù  NYT customer service tells me that sometimes puzzles are switched, but none of their suggestions allow me to retrieve the one that everyone else seems to have enjoyed. Have I been singled out, or have others found themselves Perked when they wanted to be Punched?

I solved it fine in well under 10 mins but I still don't get the theme even after reading the comments and you know what? I don't really care. Decent debut but don't try so hard to be clever next time. 

PS - What would a NYT crossword be without including the dreaded Yoko Ono? Sigh.

Ok, I can't get "View All Replies" to work on most posts.

It flashes for a second, but doesn't present the replies.
Very nice Monday puzzle. Perfectly enjoyable without the circled letters theme. Next time the NYT asks me to edit their Monday crosswords, I‚Äôll make a point of dropping superfluities. üòâ
Impressive and fun debut, congrats!  I'm a fan of puns so this one made me smile.  It was cool that 15A solved to ANTE.

Didn‚Äôt beat my best but significantly faster than average. Took about 3 passes clue by clue each time adding a few more from new crossings. I like it when I don‚Äôt have to jump to an easy clue but just go in order. Like putting on layers of paint in a Bob Ross show. ‚ÄúNo mistakes, just happy accidents‚Äù.

THINKINGCAP was fun, thought it could be HAT but turned out not. Couldn‚Äôt think of CHICKENTENDER, don‚Äôt eat much of this so didn‚Äôt really know that these were different. Reminds of the guy who invents and patents meat cuts!

MPAA felt right and filled it in blank even though I wasn‚Äôt sure. Funny how some things linger as an impression rather than as  knowledge .
Good puzzle...though the level was a little tough for a Monday. Thinking cap was cute, and I was just telling my husband how much I prefer a high five to a fist bump!!

This was not Monday level. I'm pretty consistent with Mondays under 5:00, but this one got me to 8 and a half! After my first pass on Across clues, I had many less clues completed than usual.  Still completed, but felt more like a Tuesday or a mild Wednesday to me!

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[What's heard exactly twice in a lifetime?]  (4)(1)
[The works?]  (6)


LONG I
OEUVRE
@Lewis Love these weekly recaps!

@SP

Shin bone?

@ad absurdum

It's called an "ace" not a "one". Duh.

@jennifer anistonurdum

You must have loved yesterday‚Äôs puzzle

@Liz Evans
Three ops, actually: 33D is AesOP
@Janis I wondered about that too!
@Janis. But for me it made a gimme out of what otherwise would have been a complete unknown, I wouldn‚Äôt even know in what area Walgreens works, let alone a competitor.
@Francis Ditto on the 'thinking hat' / 'hello' situation

Max,

Next time, before you take a guess (at the football coach's name for that cross), look at the theme: it should have given you JACK ... and the K for the cross.
"... what is a 'proper name' anyway?" It's another way of saying "proper noun." https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/propername "So what is a name that isn't proper?" Good question!

@Barry Ancona

(Ahem.) Not a football coach!! I know you were simply repeating the OP's comment, but football was not Michael Jordan's second pro sport. üòâ

G,

Yes, I was simply quoting the OP. I knew which sport. My nephew played for LMHS.

@Barry Ancona
Your suggestion is excellent, of course. But I would never have made that connection. I wouldn't have connected KING with JACK, maybe because I haven't played a card game in over 40 years, and even before that, very rarely. I did solve the name using crossers though.

@Jane

It‚Äôs KITSCH, with an S.

@Jane

MPAA was tricky!! I knew it was something along those lines but couldn't remember exactly. But POI is crosswordese, so it's good to remember in relation to Hawaiian food. (A luau is in part a feast.) ‚ò∫Ô∏è

@Jacqui J It could only be Jackson as coach for both Michael Jordan (Bulls) and Kobe Bryant (Lakers). And um, there were a lot of Lakers coaches between Riley and Jackson ‚Äì apparently even Magic Johnson was a coach in LA for a minute! During that era (all of the 90's!) Pat Riley was with the Knicks and then the Miami Heat, where he stillbis but not as coach. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Los_Angeles_Lakers_head_coaches?wprov=sfla1 Yesterday you my fellow Gen-Xer were reminiscing about Friends. Well now you can tell what kind of TV I was watching back then! But now we have the WNBA. Go Liberty! üóΩ

@Jacqui J

The clueing of 10A and 70A tells us that HIGH will be in 70A. Look at clues for answers that are spread across multiple slots in the grid and you'll see that the first part of the answer is always (in my experience, anyway) the one that says [With X-Across, . . .]

@G thanks for the link! Yes, many coaches between them üòÜü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I moved to AZ in ‚Äò91 right after college and everyone there were Suns fans. I had a couple of the players as my customers at the bank where I worked. So I guess I started paying more attention to the Suns than the Lakers at that point. When in Rome‚Ä¶

@Eric Hougland yes, I should have paid closer attention that the main clue was at 70A and would have absolutely been the start of the phrase ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I still think it would have been more appealing to see HIGH at the top of the grid, but obviously that would have completely changed the entire fill. I am still in awe of every constructor and their ability to do this.

@SBK glad to hear that! My husband‚Äôs parents and his aunt are the only ones who regularly send cards for every holiday, birthday and thanks. We used to get hundreds of cards during the holidays each year and it‚Äôs dwindled down to the twenties. I personally used to send out just over 200 each holiday and it‚Äôs down to 75 ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è I receive more ecards now I guess. It‚Äôs becoming a lost art I think. 

Very sorry to hear about your loss.

@Jacqui J
And Eric Hougland

Thanks for your kind condolences. It's almost three years since my sister died but it's still tough. I'm now the last remaining person from my family in North America. (I've got some cousins overseas.) But this is the way of the world, if you live long enough

Joke for this occasion:
DOCTOR: Well, Mrs. X, I see you're depressed.
MRS. X: I'm old, I'm sick, everything aches, and all my friends and family have died. Of course I'm depressed!

@Margot

It‚Äôs not a perfect science, don‚Äôt get frustrated. Just keep plugging away, learn from the clues you missed, I promise you, you will be breezing through before you know it.

@Margot

This was a little meatier than the average Monday in my opinion.  I too, looked for a while before I found a gimme, and I can generally do late week puzzles as well.

If you haven't already, there are a lot of archived puzzles that you can hone your skills on.

But SP's promise is real.  Just keep cranking.
@Margot  xwstats.com agrees with your sentiment, so far it's rated as "hard" for a Monday.

@Margot - Now I am curious as to what was so hard.  I only looked up the correct spelling of the end of OSIRIS, making sure there wasn't a "u" in there.  Perhaps it's a generational thing, with Hi-C and Phil Jackson.  MERCH is a newer thing.  The key may be to read widely.
@Margot IDK. Maybe the constructor was more on my wavelength because it worked for me.

@Margot

The best solve is going through each block like a grid on a map comparing across and down answers. 

Set it down and take breaks.  Your brain is still mulling and trying to find the answer.  When you come back it will get easier. 

Except Thursday. Because you never know what trick the editors will want on any particular Thursday.

@Red Carpet Yes, thank you for that. As a technical writer [retired] and even fiction, walking away & returning later is successful technique. I've done it with these puzzles as well.  When I am sailing along on a Mon. puzzzle, walking away & then returning is a good method. Sometimes, I will do that for several days, particularly for a Tues puzzle.
@jennie If you are asking me that, then, obviously, you've have no difficulty & I wouldn't begin to annotate all the clues that have left me clueless. I wouldn't know where to begin!
@SP Thank you for the encouragement. I appreciate all of what you guys say. It really helps...

@Margot

This former technical writer would kindly suggest you think of your audience when posting comments: it is rare that a member of the Games staff would see your comment and pass it along. So requesting they "rethink the order" likely won't reach anyone who could affect that. However as you see, the fellow commenters will absolutely support and try to help out! 

My suggestion on that count ‚Äì in addition to @Red Carpet's very solid one ‚Äì is maybe antithetical. Try and move quickly: if an answer doesn't come immediately to mind, move to the next. Try not to let the blank squares distract, because on the next round you'll have a few crosses ‚Äì and it acts almost as if you had walked away and returned! 

This puzzle had quite a number of "crossword glue" answers. I had NO idea for [Opening stake]... But it sounds like poker to me (never played!), so I plopped in ANTE. I only know this from crosswords, and wasn't sure I had it right ‚Äì but sure enough, it worked! 

Look for a little book called Crosswordese. (I got it as a Christmas present last year.) As it says on the back cover, "Crossword puzzles have a language all their own." And it explains, in detail! 

Good luck!

@Margot

I've been doing these puzzles for over two years now, and I often ace Fridays, and sometimes Saturdays, too. I struggled with this one and found an utterly unenjoyable slog. An inane theme, trivia-heavy fill... I'm not surprised you're struggling. Most of the puzzles around here are better though.

@Margot

I've solved over 10,000 crossword puzzles. My time on this one was a little bit longer than my average for Monday, but certainly within my Monday‚ÄìTuesday range. 

I wholeheartedly second G's suggestion to move on if an answer doesn't come quickly. At least for me, a good part of solving is recognizing letter patterns and filling in what makes a common word. Making multiple trips through the grid is usually more productive than staring at a single clue for several minutes trying to understand whatever it is you're missing.

Crossword solving is a skill that takes time to develop. But like SP said, if you keep at it, you'll get better quicker than you might expect.

Good luck, and have fun!

@Margot it‚Äôs more of a Tuesday than a Monday. Possibly early evening Monday. 

Certainly solving these is an acquired skill and not an IQ test. Keep at it and you‚Äôll get the hang of it. It can become great fun and this little community here is  kind.

@G
Another ex-technical writer here. Who knew?!

@SBK

Amazing!! 

I always thought of technical writing as being primarily problem solving, so perhaps there's an overlap; crosswords help scratch that itch so to speak. 

Fits right in with @Eric H's apt reminder that a lot of crossword solving is about recognizing letter patterns!

@Margot I found it a little difficult for a Monday too. For me, the level of difficulty would have been a better Tuesday fit. Sometimes the editors evaluate a puzzle as harder or easier than most solvers find it to be. Other times, a puzzle ends up being harder or easier for me than for most people. No harm done either way, it seems to happen in both directions (hard puzzles too early and easy puzzles too late in the week), neither very frequently. Difficulty is hard to evaluate because one person‚Äôs gimmes are another person‚Äôs stumpers. Unless this becomes a pattern of misplaced puzzles, I don‚Äôt think the editors are doing something wrong. Definitely a frustrating solve for both me and you today though!

@Margot

One thing I‚Äôd add to the other responses you‚Äôve gotten is that crossword difficulty is a *highly* personalized quality.

To use myself as an example: I do the puzzle every day of the week, without any external assistance (that is, on the rare occasions that I cheat, I do so in the app so that my streak reflects it), and usually finish pretty quickly‚Ä¶but I got stumped HARD on the final two squares last Wednesday, which required inputting non-alphabetic characters (specifically, the numbers 2 and 4). After spinning for nearly half an hour, I caved and cheated‚Ä¶and came to the Wordplay comments to find that the gimmick hadn‚Äôt given anyone else much trouble ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Anyway, the above anecdote is representative of my solving experiences: I have often raced through puzzles that tormented much of the commentariat, and just as often I have struggled mightily with a puzzle that the community deemed fun and easy.

@Margot

I solve the puzzles top the bottom and left to right. Normally, I can finish a Monday almost by the across entries alone. Today, I had almost no fill after going through the across clues. However, for me, the downs were more forgiving. I finished right between my Monday and Tuesday times

My advice:
1. Practice, practice, practice
2. Use the crosses. Flip back and forth between down and across to gradually fill in the board.
3. Either you know an answer or you don't. I spend 1 second per clue or less. If I know it, I fill it in, if not, I'll come back to it once I have some crosses. See point 2.
4. When you're just starting out don't be afraid to look things up. That's how you learn.
